description: A signal sent by a receiver to indicate successful receipt of a message or data packet.
A list of permissions attached to an object that specifies which users or system processes can access the object and what operations they can perform.
A type of DSL broadband communications technology used for connecting to the internet, with faster download speeds than upload speeds.
A symmetric encryption algorithm widely used across the globe to secure data, known for its speed and security.
A set of rules and protocols for building and interacting with software applications, allowing different software systems to communicate with each other.
A protocol used for mapping an IP address to a physical machine address that is recognized in the local network.
A networking technology that uses fixed-size cells to transmit data, voice, and video over a single network.
A standardized exterior gateway protocol used to exchange routing information between different networks on the internet.
The basic building block of a wireless LAN, consisting of a group of stations that communicate with each other.
A classification of twisted pair cables used in networking, with different categories indicating different performance levels.
The International Telegraph and Telephone Consultative Committee, which was responsible for telecommunications standards before being replaced by the ITU-T.
A protocol used to authenticate a user or network host to an authenticating entity, often used in PPP connections.
A method for allocating IP addresses and routing internet traffic that replaces the older system based on classes A, B, and C.
The average rate at which a network agrees to transfer information under normal conditions, used in Frame Relay networks.
A user interface that allows users to interact with the computer's operating system or software by typing commands.
Equipment such as telephones, routers, and modems that is located at the customer's premises and connected to the service provider's network.
The primary component of a computer that performs most of the processing inside a computer.
An error-detecting code used to detect accidental changes to raw data in digital networks and storage devices.
A specific type of CRC used in X.25 and HDLC protocols to ensure data integrity.
A technology used in traditional television sets and computer monitors, where electrons are fired at a phosphorescent screen to create images.
A network protocol that listens for a carrier signal before trying to transmit data to avoid collisions in wireless networks.
A network protocol that detects collisions in a network and takes steps to resolve them, commonly used in Ethernet networks.
A device used to connect a digital data line to a router or other network device, converting digital data from a local area network to a form suitable for a wide area network.
A technology used in microprocessors, microcontrollers, and other digital logic circuits, known for its low power consumption.
A system for storing, organizing, and managing digital assets such as images, videos, and documents.
Equipment that provides a path for data transmission, typically including modems and other devices that connect to a network.
A company that was a major American manufacturer of computers and related products, known for its PDP and VAX series of computers.
A symmetric-key algorithm for the encryption of digital data, now considered obsolete and replaced by the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES).
A network management protocol used to dynamically assign IP addresses to devices on a network, allowing them to communicate with other IP networks.
A type of memory module used in computers, characterized by having separate electrical contacts on each side of the module.
A hierarchical system for naming resources on the internet, translating human-readable domain names into IP addresses.
A type of random-access memory that stores each bit of data in a separate capacitor, commonly used in computers and other devices.
A family of technologies that provide internet access by transmitting digital data over the wires of a local telephone network.
A network device that receives signals from multiple customer DSL connections and aggregates them onto a high-speed backbone line.
Equipment that serves as the source or destination of data, typically including computers, terminals, and other devices that generate or use data.
A framework for managing and tracking hardware and software components in a computer system.
A unique identifier assigned to network interfaces for communications on the physical network segment, also known as a MAC address.
An advanced distance-vector routing protocol used on a computer network for automating routing decisions and configuration.
A marker used in data transmission to indicate the end of a data frame, commonly used in protocols like HDLC.
A set of interconnected basic service sets (BSS) that appear as a single network to the logical link control layer at any station associated with one of those BSSs.
An independent agency of the United States government that regulates communications by radio, television, wire, satellite, and cable.
An independent agency of the United States government that regulates communications by radio, television, wire, satellite, and cable.
An error-detecting code added to a frame in Ethernet networks to ensure data integrity during transmission.
A set of standards for data transmission on fiber optic lines in a local area network that can extend in range up to 200 kilometers.
A standard network protocol used to transfer files from one host to another over a TCP-based network, such as the internet.
A transceiver that converts electric currents to optical signals and vice versa, used in gigabit Ethernet and fiber channel networks.
A unit of data transfer rate equal to one billion bits per second, commonly used to measure bandwidth and data transfer speeds.
A technology that enables gigabit Ethernet transmission over plastic optical fiber, offering a cost-effective and flexible alternative to traditional glass fiber.
A bit-oriented code-transparent synchronous data link layer protocol developed by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO).'
A protocol used for transmitting hypertext requests and information on the internet, forming the foundation of data communication for the World Wide Web.
An extension of HTTP that uses encryption to secure data communication over a computer network, widely used for secure transactions on the internet.
A form of cloud computing that provides virtualized computing resources over the internet, allowing businesses to rent infrastructure like servers and storage.
A network layer protocol used by network devices to diagnose network communication issues and report errors.
A distribution frame in a building or campus that connects and manages telecommunications wiring between an MDF and individual devices.
A system that monitors network traffic for suspicious activity and alerts administrators of potential security breaches.
An internet standard protocol used by email clients to retrieve messages from a mail server, allowing users to view and manage their email.
A set of rules governing the format of data sent over the internet or other network, responsible for addressing and routing packets of data.
A network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic to prevent and respond to potential threats.
A routing protocol designed to move information efficiently within a computer network, used primarily in large service provider networks.
A set of communication standards for simultaneous digital transmission of voice, video, data, and other network services over traditional telephone networks.
A company that provides individuals and organizations access to the internet and other related services.
A specialized agency of the United Nations responsible for issues related to information and communication technologies, including setting global telecommunications standards.
A unit of data transfer rate equal to one thousand bits per second, commonly used to measure internet connection speeds.
A protocol used to control the bundling of several physical ports together to form a single logical channel for increased bandwidth and redundancy.
A network that connects computers and other devices within a limited area, such as a home, school, or office building.
A sublayer of the data link layer in the OSI model that provides interface and control functions to ensure reliable data transfer.
A unique identifier assigned to network interfaces for communications on the physical network segment, also known as a hardware address.
A system for managing and organizing media assets, often used in conjunction with digital asset management systems.
A network that connects multiple local area networks within a metropolitan area, providing high-speed connectivity over a larger geographic area.
A unit of data transfer rate equal to one million bits per second, commonly used to measure internet connection speeds.
A distribution frame that connects and manages telecommunications wiring between an IDF and external communication lines.
A database used for managing the entities in a communication network, commonly used with the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP).
A standard interface used to connect a network device, such as a computer or router, to a physical medium, such as Ethernet.
An alliance that develops standards for networking over coaxial cable, enabling high-speed data transfer and multimedia distribution within homes.
A technique used in high-performance telecommunications networks to direct data from one network node to the next based on short path labels rather than long network addresses.
The largest size of a packet or frame that can be sent in a packet- or frame-based network, ensuring efficient data transmission.
A security solution that controls access to a network by enforcing policies, ensuring that only authorized and compliant devices can connect.
A storage device connected to a network that allows data to be accessed by multiple users and devices, providing centralized data storage and management.
A method used in networking to modify network address information in packet headers while in transit, enabling multiple devices on a local network to share a single public IP address.
A type of network that does not support broadcast or multicast traffic, commonly used in technologies like Frame Relay and ATM.
A hardware component that connects a computer to a network, allowing it to communicate with other devices on the network.
A method of mapping a binary signal to a physical signal for transmission over a transmission medium, where the signal does not return to zero between bits.
A method of mapping a binary signal to a physical signal for transmission over a transmission medium, where a change in the signal level represents a binary 1 and no change represents a binary 0.
A type of memory that retains its data even when the power is turned off, commonly used for storing firmware and configuration settings.
A conceptual framework used to understand and implement network protocols in seven layers, developed jointly by the ISO and ITU.
A routing protocol used to find the best path for data exchange in an IP network, based on the shortest path first (SPF) algorithm.
A 24-bit number that uniquely identifies a vendor, manufacturer, or organization, used as the first part of a MAC address.
A simple authentication protocol used to validate users before allowing them access to a network, transmitting passwords in plaintext.
A type of network address translation that maps multiple private IP addresses to a single public IP address using different ports.
A cloud computing service that provides a platform allowing customers to develop, run, and manage applications without dealing with the underlying infrastructure.
A general-purpose computer designed for individual use, capable of running a wide variety of software applications.
A type of software application that helps users manage personal information such as contacts, appointments, and tasks.
A method used to digitally represent analog signals, commonly used in digital telephony and audio recording.
A unit of data specified in a protocol of a given layer, such as a segment, packet, or frame, used for communication between network devices.
A protocol used by email clients to retrieve messages from a mail server, allowing users to download and manage their email locally.
A physical location where different networks or communication devices connect to the internet or other networks.
A diagnostic testing sequence run by a computer’s firmware or software to check hardware components before starting the operating system.
A traditional telephone service that uses analog signal transmission over copper wires.
A data link protocol used to establish a direct connection between two networking nodes, providing authentication, encryption, and compression.
A method for implementing virtual private networks, using a control channel over TCP and a GRE tunnel to encapsulate PPP packets.
A term referring to government-owned or regulated telecommunications services, including telephone and telegraph services.
A Cisco proprietary protocol that allows each VLAN to have a separate spanning tree, enhancing network performance and redundancy.
A networking protocol that provides centralized authentication, authorization, and accounting for users who connect and use a network service.
A type of computer memory that can be accessed randomly, used for storing working data and machine code currently in use.
A protocol used to map a known MAC address to an IP address, allowing a device to request its IP address from a gateway server.
A type of memory module developed by Rambus Inc., used in computers for high-speed data transfer.
A formal document from the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) that describes the specifications, protocols, procedures, and policies for the internet.
A distance-vector routing protocol used in local and wide area networks to determine the best route for data packets based on the hop count.
A method of encoding data to increase the storage density and reliability of magnetic storage media.
A type of non-volatile memory used in computers and other electronic devices to store firmware and other permanent data.
An evolution of the Spanning Tree Protocol that provides faster convergence and improved network topology changes.
A protocol used for delivering audio and video over IP networks, providing end-to-end network transport functions suitable for real-time data.
A software distribution model in which applications are hosted by a service provider and made available to customers over the internet.
A protocol used in synchronous communication networks to manage the transmission of data between network devices.
An approach to networking that uses software-based controllers to manage network resources and traffic, allowing for more flexible and efficient network management.
A field in a data frame that indicates the start of the frame, used in Ethernet and HDLC protocols.
A compact, hot-pluggable transceiver used for both telecommunication and data communications applications.
An obsolete protocol designed to provide secure communication over the internet, rarely used today.
A protocol used to obtain an IP address for a serial interface in a Cisco router, similar to ARP but for serial links.
An older protocol used for point-to-point serial connections, now largely replaced by PPP.
A type of memory module with a single row of connectors, used in older computers for RAM.
A protocol used for sending email messages between servers, as well as from email clients to servers.
A proprietary networking architecture developed by IBM to connect and manage communication between computers and devices.
A protocol used to encapsulate network layer protocols over IEEE 802 networks, providing a way to identify the protocol being carried.
A protocol used for network management, allowing administrators to monitor and manage network devices and their functions.
A marker used in data transmission to indicate the beginning of a data frame, ensuring proper synchronization.
A type of memory that uses bistable latching circuitry to store each bit, providing faster access times than DRAM.
A protocol used to securely access and manage network devices and servers over an unsecured network.
A unique identifier that names a wireless local area network, allowing devices to connect to the correct network.
A network protocol that prevents loops in network topologies by creating a spanning tree, ensuring a loop-free network.
A control flag in the TCP header used to initiate a connection between two hosts in a TCP/IP network.
A suite of communication protocols used to interconnect network devices on the internet, providing end-to-end data communication.
A method of transmitting multiple signals over a single communication channel by dividing the channel into time slots.
A simple file transfer protocol used for transferring files over a network, typically used for booting devices and transferring configuration files.
A trade association that develops standards for the telecommunications industry, including cabling and network infrastructure.
A security model where a device or user is trusted the first time they connect, with subsequent connections being monitored for anomalies.
A communication protocol used for time-sensitive transmissions such as video playback or DNS lookups, providing low-latency and loss-tolerating connections.
A reference to a web resource that specifies its location on a computer network and a mechanism for retrieving it.
A standard for connecting peripherals to a computer, providing data transfer and power supply through a single cable.
A type of twisted pair cabling used in networking, characterized by the absence of additional shielding to protect against electromagnetic interference.
A logical connection created within a network to ensure reliable data transfer between two devices.
A network configuration that allows devices on different physical LANs to communicate as if they were on the same LAN, improving network management and security.
A technique used in IP addressing that allows for more efficient use of IP address space by varying the length of the subnet mask.
A software-based emulation of a physical computer, allowing multiple operating systems to run on a single physical machine.
A technology that creates a secure, encrypted connection over a less secure network, such as the internet, to provide remote access and protect data.
A telecommunications network that extends over a large geographic area, connecting multiple local area networks (LANs).'
A security protocol for wireless networks that provides data encryption, now considered insecure and largely replaced by WPA.
A technology that allows electronic devices to connect to a wireless local area network (WLAN), based on the IEEE 802.11 standards.
A device that manages wireless network access points, providing centralized control and management of the wireless network.
A security protocol developed to secure wireless networks, providing stronger data protection and network access control than WEP.
A system of interlinked hypertext documents and multimedia content accessed via the internet, forming the basis of the World Wide Web.
